<h3 style="color: darkorange;">Rennet Casein</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Many <b>common steps</b> with acid CN production</li>
    <br>
    <li><u>But</u>, coagulation is <b>enzymatic</b> not isolectric</li>
    <br>
    <li>There is <b>no acidification</b> so little change in [CCP]</li>
    <br>
    <li>Ingredient is used in <b>analogue cheese</b></li>

<section data-transition="slide" data-background="#4B226D" data-background-transition="zoom">
<h2 style="color: #FE82E5;">Cross-flow Filtration</h2>
<p>
    To make acid or rennet casein the proteins must be <i style="color: #EC71D2;">(bio)chemically modified</i> before filtration.
    If smaller-pore filters are used it is possible to recover proteins without causing
    these modifications. However, to push liquid through these filters greater <i style="color: #EC71D2;">pressure</i>
    and <i style="color: #EC71D2;">turbulence</i> is required.
</p>
<p>
    A demo of the UCC equipment by <i>PhD student <b>Tom France</b>
    can be found on the UCC <a href="https://www.ucc.ie/en/canvas/">Canvas</a> page</i>
</p>
</section>
